title: Brownian Motion Increments
notes: Stochastic Calculus Foundations - Stochastic Processes
column5: This equation describes the increments of Brownian motion. The increment over a small time interval delta t is normally distributed with mean 0 and variance delta t. Increments over non-overlapping intervals are independent
column6: which is a key property of Brownian motion.

title: Quadratic Variation
notes: Stochastic Calculus Foundations - Stochastic Processes
column5: This equation defines the quadratic variation of Brownian motion. [W
column6: W]_t represents the quadratic variation up to time t
column7: which equals t. Quadratic variation measures the accumulated variance of the stochastic process and is crucial in stochastic integration.

title: Quadratic Variation Property
notes: This equation shows how quadratic variation is calculated as the limit of squared increments. As the partition becomes finer
column5: the sum of squared increments converges to t. This property distinguishes Brownian motion from differentiable functions.

title: Geometric Brownian Motion
equation_latex: dS_t = mu * S_t * dt + sigma * S_t * dW_t
notes: This is the Geometric Brownian Motion (GBM) SDE for asset prices. dS_t represents the change in asset price
column5: mu is the drift (expected return)
column7: S_t is the current price
column9: and dW_t is the Brownian motion increment. GBM ensures positive prices and lognormal distribution.

title: GBM Solution
equation_latex: S_t = S_0 * exp((mu - 0.5 * sigma^2) * t + sigma * W_t)
notes: This equation gives the solution to the GBM SDE. S_t represents the asset price at time t
column5: S_0 is the initial price
column7: sigma is the volatility
column8: and W_t is Brownian motion. The solution shows that log(S_t/S_0) is normally distributed

title: Lognormal Distribution
notes: Stochastic Calculus Foundations - Stochastic Processes
column5: This equation describes the lognormal distribution of GBM prices. ln(S_t/S_0) represents the log return
column6: which is normally distributed with mean (mu - 0.5*sigma^2)*t and variance sigma^2*t. The -0.5*sigma^2 term arises from Ito's Lemma.

title: General Diffusion Process

column12: and dW_t is the Brownian motion increment. This form encompasses many financial models.

title: Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Process
equation_latex: dX_t = theta * (mu - X_t) * dt + sigma * dW_t
notes: This is the Ornstein-Uhlenbeck (OU) process SDE. dX_t represents the change
column5: theta is the mean reversion speed
column7: X_t is the current value
column9: and dW_t is Brownian motion. The OU process exhibits mean reversion and is used for interest rates and volatility.

title: Mean-Reverting Level
notes: This equation shows that the OU process reverts to its long-term mean mu. As time goes to infinity
column5: the expected value of X_t converges to mu. Mean reversion is a key property of many financial time series

title: Ito's Lemma
equation_latex: dY_t = (partial f/partial t + mu * partial f/partial x + 0.5 * sigma^2 * partial^2 f/partial x^2) * dt + sigma * partial f/partial x * dW_t
notes: This is Ito's Lemma for a function f(X_t
column5: t) of an Ito process. dY_t represents the change in Y_t = f(X_t
column7: partial f/partial t and partial f/partial x are partial derivatives
column8: and the 0.5*sigma^2 term is the Ito correction. Ito's Lemma is the chain rule for stochastic calculus.

title: Ito's Lemma for GBM
equation_latex: d ln(S_t) = (mu - 0.5 * sigma^2) * dt + sigma * dW_t
notes: This is Ito's Lemma applied to ln(S_t) for GBM. d ln(S_t) represents the change in log price
column5: mu is the drift
column7: dt is the time increment
column8: and dW_t is Brownian motion. The -0.5*sigma^2 term is the Ito correction for the logarithmic transformation.

title: Ito's Lemma for f(S_t) = S_t^2
equation_latex: d(S_t^2) = (2 * mu * S_t^2 + sigma^2 * S_t^2) * dt + 2 * sigma * S_t^2 * dW_t
notes: This is Ito's Lemma applied to f(S_t) = S_t^2. The drift term includes both the 2*mu*S_t^2 term from ordinary calculus and the sigma^2*S_t^2 Ito correction. This example shows how Ito's Lemma differs from the ordinary chain rule.

title: Stochastic Integral
notes: This equation defines the Ito stochastic integral. I_t represents the integral of the adapted process X_s with respect to Brownian motion W_s. The stochastic integral is defined as the limit of Riemann sums
column5: with the integrand evaluated at the left endpoint of each interval.

title: Ito Isometry
equation_latex: E[(integral_0^t X_s * dW_s)^2] = E[integral_0^t X_s^2 ds]
notes: This equation defines the Ito Isometry property. The expectation of the squared stochastic integral equals the expectation of the integral of the squared integrand. Ito Isometry is crucial for calculating variances of stochastic integrals.

title: Martingale Property
notes: This equation shows that the stochastic integral is a martingale. The conditional expectation of the future integral given information at time t is zero. The martingale property is fundamental to risk-neutral valuation in finance.

title: Ito Product Rule
equation_latex: d(X_t * Y_t) = X_t * dY_t + Y_t * dX_t + d[X
notes: Stochastic Calculus Foundations - Stochastic Processes
column5: This is the Ito product rule for two Ito processes X_t and Y_t. d(X_t * Y_t) represents the change in the product
column7: Y]_t is the quadratic covariation. The product rule includes the quadratic covariation term
column8: which is absent in ordinary calculus.

title: Quadratic Covariation
notes: Stochastic Calculus Foundations - Stochastic Processes
column5: This equation defines the quadratic covariation between two Ito processes. [X
column7: and sigma_X(s) and sigma_Y(s) are the diffusion coefficients. Quadratic covariation measures the co-movement of two stochastic processes.

title: Girsanov Theorem (Change of Measure)
notes: This equation defines the Girsanov transformation for changing probability measures. dW_t^Q represents Brownian motion under the new measure Q
column5: dW_t^P is Brownian motion under the original measure P
column6: and lambda_t is the market price of risk. Girsanov's theorem is essential for risk-neutral valuation.

title: Market Price of Risk
notes: This equation defines the market price of risk. lambda_t represents the Sharpe ratio of the asset
column5: mu_t is the expected return
column7: and sigma_t is the volatility. The market price of risk measures the excess return per unit of risk.

title: Risk-Neutral Dynamics
equation_latex: dS_t = r_t * S_t * dt + sigma_t * S_t * dW_t^Q
notes: This equation gives the risk-neutral dynamics of an asset price. Under the risk-neutral measure Q
column5: the drift mu is replaced by the risk-free rate r_t
column6: and dW_t^Q is Brownian motion under Q. Risk-neutral dynamics are used for derivative pricing.

title: Radon-Nikodym Derivative
equation_latex: Z_T = exp(-integral_0^T lambda_s * dW_s^P - 0.5 * integral_0^T lambda_s^2 ds)
notes: This equation defines the Radon-Nikodym derivative for changing from measure P to Q. Z_T represents the likelihood ratio
column5: lambda_s is the market price of risk
column6: and dW_s^P is Brownian motion under P. The Radon-Nikodym derivative is used to calculate expectations under the new measure.

title: Novikov Condition
notes: This equation is the Novikov condition
column5: which ensures that the Radon-Nikodym derivative is a martingale. The condition requires that the exponential of half the integrated squared market price of risk has finite expectation. Novikov's condition is a sufficient condition for Girsanov's theorem.

title: Feynman-Kac Formula
main_category: t) = E[exp(-integral_t^T r(s) ds) * g(X_T) | X_t = x]
notes: Stochastic Calculus Foundations - Stochastic Differential Equations
column5: This equation defines the Feynman-Kac formula
column6: which connects PDEs to SDEs. u(x

column10: and X_t is the underlying process. Feynman-Kac is fundamental to derivative pricing.

title: Kolmogorov Forward Equation
equation_latex: partial p / partial t = -partial (mu * p) / partial x + 0.5 * partial^2 (sigma^2 * p) / partial x^2
main_category: Stochastic Calculus Foundations - Stochastic Differential Equations
notes: This equation defines the Kolmogorov forward (Fokker-Planck) equation for the transition density p(x
column5: t). p(x
column7: mu is the drift
column8: and sigma is the diffusion. The forward equation describes how the probability density evolves over time.

title: Kolmogorov Backward Equation
equation_latex: partial p / partial t = mu * partial p / partial x + 0.5 * sigma^2 * partial^2 p / partial x^2
main_category: Stochastic Calculus Foundations - Stochastic Differential Equations
notes: This equation defines the Kolmogorov backward equation. Unlike the forward equation
column5: the backward equation evolves backward in time from the terminal condition. The backward equation is used in option pricing and expectation calculations.

title: Strong Solution
notes: s) dW_s
column5: Stochastic Calculus Foundations - Stochastic Differential Equations
column6: This equation gives the strong solution to an SDE. X_t represents the solution at time t
column7: X_0 is the initial condition
column8: and the integrals represent the accumulated drift and diffusion. A strong solution is adapted to the filtration generated by the Brownian motion.

title: Weak Solution
notes: s) dW_s
column5: Stochastic Calculus Foundations - Stochastic Differential Equations
column6: This equation gives the weak solution to an SDE. A weak solution requires existence of a probability space and Brownian motion such that the equation holds
column7: but the Brownian motion may be different from the original one. Weak solutions are sufficient for pricing applications.

title: Existence and Uniqueness
notes: t)| + |sigma(x

column7: Stochastic Calculus Foundations - Stochastic Differential Equations
column8: This equation is the Lipschitz condition for existence and uniqueness of SDE solutions. mu and sigma must satisfy a Lipschitz condition in x and a linear growth condition. These conditions ensure that a strong solution exists and is unique.

title: Martingale Representation Theorem
main_category: Stochastic Calculus Foundations - Stochastic Differential Equations
notes: This theorem states that any square-integrable martingale M_t can be represented as a stochastic integral. phi_s is an adapted process
column5: and dW_s is Brownian motion. This theorem is fundamental to hedging and completeness in finance.

title: Stochastic Exponential
notes: Stochastic Calculus Foundations - Stochastic Differential Equations
column5: This equation defines the stochastic exponential (Doléans-Dade exponential). E(X)_t represents the stochastic exponential of a semimartingale X_t
column7: X]_t is the quadratic variation. The stochastic exponential solves dE(X)_t = E(X)_t * dX_t.

title: Doléans-Dade Exponential
notes: Stochastic Calculus Foundations - Stochastic Differential Equations
column5: This equation defines the Doléans-Dade exponential used in Girsanov's theorem. Z_t represents the Radon-Nikodym derivative
column6: lambda_t is the market price of risk
column7: and dW_t is Brownian motion. The solution is Z_t = exp(-integral_0^t lambda_s dW_s - 0.5 * integral_0^t lambda_s^2 ds).

title: Martingale Representation for GBM
equation_latex: S_t = S_0 + integral_0^t mu * S_s ds + integral_0^t sigma * S_s dW_s
main_category: Stochastic Calculus Foundations - Stochastic Differential Equations
notes: This equation represents GBM as an Ito integral. S_t represents the GBM price
column5: mu is the drift
column7: and the integrals represent the accumulated drift and diffusion. This representation is used in hedging and risk management.

column10: This equation defines multi-dimensional Brownian motion. dW_t is a vector of n correlated Brownian motions
column11: with correlation matrix rho. Multi-dimensional Brownian motion is used for modeling multiple correlated assets or risk factors.

title: Correlation Structure
notes: t}] = rho_{ij} * dt

column6: This equation defines the correlation structure of multi-dimensional Brownian motion. rho_{ij} represents the correlation between Brownian motions i and j. The correlation matrix must be positive semi-definite. Correlations are crucial for pricing multi-asset derivatives.

title: Multi-Dimensional SDE
notes: t) * dW_t
column5: Stochastic Calculus Foundations - Stochastic Processes
column6: This equation defines a multi-dimensional SDE. dX_t is a vector of state variables
column7: mu is the drift vector
column9: and dW_t is multi-dimensional Brownian motion. Multi-dimensional SDEs are used for complex financial models.

title: Multi-Dimensional Ito's Lemma
equation_latex: dY_t = (partial f/partial t + nabla f * mu + 0.5 * tr(Sigma * Sigma^T * Hessian f)) * dt + (nabla f * Sigma) * dW_t
notes: This is Ito's Lemma for multi-dimensional processes. nabla f is the gradient
column5: Hessian f is the Hessian matrix
column7: Sigma is the diffusion matrix
column8: and tr is the trace operator. The multi-dimensional version includes a matrix trace term for the Ito correction.

title: Stopped Process
notes: Stochastic Calculus Foundations - Stochastic Processes
column5: This equation defines a stopped process. X_{t^tau} represents the process stopped at the stopping time tau. Stopping times are random times such that the event {tau <= t} is determined by information up to time t. Stopped processes are used for pricing American options.

title: Optional Stopping Theorem
equation_latex: E[X_tau] = E[X_0] for bounded stopping times tau
notes: This theorem states that for a martingale X_t
column5: the expected value at a bounded stopping time equals the initial expected value. The optional stopping theorem is used in optimal stopping problems and American option pricing.

title: Local Martingale
equation_latex: Integral_0^t H_s * dM_s is a local martingale
notes: This equation defines a local martingale. A local martingale is a process that becomes a martingale when stopped at an increasing sequence of stopping times. Local martingales are more general than martingales and appear in many financial models.

title: Semimartingale
notes: This equation defines a semimartingale as the sum of a local martingale M_t and a finite variation process A_t. Semimartingales are the most general class of processes for which stochastic integration can be defined. Most financial models are semimartingales.

title: Predictable Representation
equation_latex: Any square-integrable martingale can be represented as a stochastic integral
main_category: Stochastic Calculus Foundations - Stochastic Differential Equations
notes: This property states that under certain conditions
column5: any martingale can be represented as a stochastic integral with respect to Brownian motion. This property is crucial for hedging and market completeness in derivative pricing.
